title: Fatal: Error starting protocol stack: listen tcp 127.0.0.1:8545: bind: Only one usage of each socket address (protocol/network address/port)
body:
I posted this question on stack, without an useful response... can you help me?
I have this error when i try tu run my second node on Geth...I used authrpc.port but still the problem persists:

I ran my node1 with these commands:

    geth --datadir node1 --networkid 2244 --allow-insecure-unlock --unlock 0x00fB51927e31f071293195CEfac6fA41ce185ee7  --http --port 30304 --http.corsdomain '*' --authrpc.port 8546 --http.vhosts '*'  --http.api admin,eth,miner,net,txpool,personal,web3 --syncmode full --nodiscover --ipcdisable --nat extip:127.0.0.1 --mine --bootnodes "enode://714e0e5f60b486b8a7d6d10518265399472e826fd190c7fe7e5da86d733042a0c870eb5e52670a5aeb84f2a47fffdfa14a3d8bd8edcd0949c7c2c4135ce3a256@127.0.0.1:0?discport=30303" console                     

And this node is set up perfectly.
When, however, I try to run the second node with:

    geth --datadir node2 --networkid 2244 --allow-insecure-unlock --unlock 0x0167539345b577d4a6551DD27DcFF15DEFb41a81  --http --port 30305 --http.corsdomain '*' --authrpc.port 8547 --http.vhosts '*'  --http.api admin,eth,miner,net,txpool,personal,web3 --syncmode full --ipcdisable --bootnodes "enode://714e0e5f60b486b8a7d6d10518265399472e826fd190c7fe7e5da86d733042a0c870eb5e52670a5aeb84f2a47fffdfa14a3d8bd8edcd0949c7c2c4135ce3a256@127.0.0.1:0?discport=30303" --mine console

This returns me:

> INFO [03-31|12:23:03.476] Started P2P networking                   self=enode://1716de0f30b7094bf4858d89ffc2e02583f20a009a67a219729c0fd477ca36d0728c125a9e08f0c2ff77e076b6ce50f2840cba7f8eaf94554d11ab2615cbf750@127.0.0.1:30305
INFO [03-31|12:23:03.476] Loaded JWT secret file                   path=C:\Users\alexc\OneDrive\Documenti\GitHub\private-blockchain-nopuppeth-2\node2\geth\jwtsecret crc32=0x55db3bf5
**Fatal: Error starting protocol stack: listen tcp 127.0.0.1:8545: bind: Only one usage of each socket address (protocol/network address/port) is normally permitted.**

Why is it trying to connect to port 8545??
I also ran a bootnode by this command, and the results is:

>  **bootnode -nodekey boot.key -addr 30303** :30303enode://714e0e5f60b486b8a7d6d10518265399472e826fd190c7fe7e5da86d733042a0c870eb5e52670a5aeb84f2a47fffdfa14a3d8bd8edcd0949c7c2c4135ce3a256@127.0.0.1:0?discport=30303       
Note: you're using cmd/bootnode, a developer tool.
We recommend using a regular node as bootstrap node for production deployments.      
INFO [03-31|12:09:42.495] New local node record                    seq=1,680,257,382,484 id=370ac589e36cff6f ip=<nil> udp=0 tcp=0

The first node successfully connected to the bootnode, while the second node doesn't boot either.
I think I found why both nodes don't connect together:

If we execute in the cmd the command "netstat -ano | findstr :8546 " After running the node1:

The command returns this process with PID 31164 in my case:
TCP 127.0.0.1:8546 0.0.0.0:0 LISTENING 31164

Similarly we can see that if I run the same command on the netstat port -ano | findstr :8545

The command returns the same process:

TCP 127.0.0.1:8546 0.0.0.0:0 LISTENING 31164

and that's why when I try to run the second node, it gives me the error I showed before, because the node tries to connect both to the indicated port (8547), but for some operating logic of the --authrpc command, yes it also connects to port 8545.

Is there a way to disable this "dual connect"? Apparently the same behavior applies to the command --http.port , in fact:

If I try to use --http.port 8546, the node will connect to both port 8546 and port 8551(in this case)

*** *****⬇️EDIT⬇️***** ***

> **I think I found why both nodes don't connect together:**

If we execute in the cmd the command `netstat -ano | findstr :8546`(after running the node1),

The command returns this process (with PID 31164 in my case):

    TCP 127.0.0.1:8546 0.0.0.0:0 LISTENING 31164

**Similarly** we can see that if I run the same command on the `netstat port -ano | findstr :8545`

The command returns the same process:

    TCP 127.0.0.1:8545 0.0.0.0:0 LISTENING 31164

and that's why when I try to run the second node, it gives me the error I showed before, because the node tries to connect both to the indicated port (8547), but for some operating logic of the --authrpc command, yes it also connects to port 8545.

Is there a way to **disable** this "dual connect"? Apparently the same behavior applies to the command --http.port , in fact:

If I try to use --http.port 8546, the node will connect to both port 8546 and port 8551(in this case)

Can someone help me please...

Here the post: [https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/148301/fatal-error-starting-protocol-stack-listen-tcp-127-0-0-18545-bind-only-one](https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/148301/fatal-error-starting-protocol-stack-listen-tcp-127-0-0-18545-bind-only-one)

- 8545 is for http port 
- 8546 is for ws port 
- 8551 for cl authrpc

```sh
$ ./build/bin/geth -h |grep 85
    --authrpc.port value           (default: 8551)
    --http.port value              (default: 8545)
    --ws.port value                (default: 8546)
```


If you run two nodes in one host and need http/ws rpc, set to different values

@jsvisa I have used different values ​​for the commands, but the error persists as you can see above. It is as if both the connection that I specify in "value" and the default one happen, every time I launch the command, how is this possible?

You need to set a different port for 3 things: `--port` which is for the p2p network, `--http.port` for JSON-RPC server and `--authrpc.port` for the Engine API. If you're setting these 3 flags to a different value in the second node you should not face a problem.

@s1na yes, that's the solution. I was given the same answer on : https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/148301/fatal-error-starting-protocol-stack-listen-tcp-127-0-0-18545-bind-only-one.

I close the issue
